application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we investigate the global stability of quaternion-valued neural networks (QVNNs) with time-varying delays. On one hand, in order to avoid the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, the QVNN is decomposed into four real-valued systems based on Hamilton rules:

1. With the Lyapunov function method, some criteria are, respectively, presented to ensure the global µ-stability and power stability of the delayed QVNN. On the other hand, by considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication and time-varying delays, the QVNN is investigated directly by the techniques of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional and the linear matrix inequality (LMI) where quaternion self-conjugate matrices and quaternion positive definite matrices are used. Some new sufficient conditions in the form of quaternion-valued LMI are, respectively, established for the global µ-stability and exponential stability of the considered QVNN. Besides, some assumptions are presented for the two different methods, which can help to choose quaternion-valued activation functions. Finally, two numerical examples are given to show the feasibility and the effectiveness of the main results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N THE past few decades, networks have been widely investigated due to its promising development and extensive applications [1]- [9], especially in fault diagnosis [10], for solving optimization problems [11], for solving linear variational inequalities [12], and others in control engineering [13]. Moreover, complex-valued neural networks (CVNNs) and real-valued neural networks (RVNNs) have been extensively studied, and many remarkable results have been presented [14]. In addition, quaternion, which was found in 1843 by the British mathematician W. R. Hamilton, has been applied successfully to array processing [15], color image processing [16], [17], and modeling of 3-D wind signals [18]. Quaternion can be regarded as a special case of Clifford algebra [19], and neural networks based on Clifford algebra have been investigated in [20], which deserve further investigation.

Considering the simple representation of quaternion, which is easy to understand the geometrical meanings, quaternionvalued neural networks (QVNNs) can be applied to various fields of engineering and science. First, anecdotal evidence suggests that the 3-D geometrical affine transformations in 3-D space can be represented efficiently and compactly by the operators of quaternions [21], [22]. For 2-D geometrical affine operations, the CVNNs can model a point in 2-D space as a single entity, instead of a set of two data items. A large study shows that the CVNNs result in an improved performance of 2-D geometrical affine operations [21]. However, for the 3-D data, including color images and body images, which can also be processed by many neurons of CVNNs or RVNNs, the QVNNs can process it with increased efficiency via direct encoding [23]. Second, for the further applications, such as 3-b parity check problem, color night vision, color image compression, and affine transformation in 3-D space [21], [23]- [26], the QVNNs can perform relatively well. For example, in color image compression, the RVNNs and the CVNNs can also be used to transmit the color signals but with a relatively poor effect. In fact, based on the three primary colors, i.e., red, green, and blue, all colors can be synthesized by the three primary colors with certain proportion, that is, a color image can be converted into three signals about the three primary colors with certain proportion, which can be transmitted via three channels i , j , and k of the QVNN, and then converted into the color image as well. Then, the RVNNs and the CVNNs cannot help to realize this perfect effect. Third, some optimization and approximation problems solved by CVNNs [28], [29] can be dealt by QVNNs with the improved behaviors, which will be investigated in the future investigation. Note that as a mathematical tool, these problems will be solved based on the stability of CVNNs or QVNNs. That is, the QVNN established for solving these problems should be stable. Then, the stability investigation for QVNNs is fundamentally important. Fourth, the investigations for QVNNs can help to facilitate the further research for ensemble control of quaternion-valued linear systems with parameter uncertainties [27], which can be applied to the attitude control of the spacecraft. Therefore, lots of real-world applications of QVNNs deserve further investigation, including the color face recognition, image compression by QVNNs, the filter design of QVNNs, the approximation problems by QVNNs, and so on. And here, we are mainly considering the fundamental stability problem of QVNNs.

The QVNNs, which can be seen as a generic extension of CVNNs, are much more complicated than the CVNNs due to the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, including the quaternion-valued states, quaternion-valued connection weights, and quaternion-valued activation functions. In complex domain, according to Liouville's theorem [30], every bounded entire function must be constant. That is to say, any activation function of a CVNN cannot be simultaneously bounded and analytic; otherwise, it is constant. In quaternion field, however, the analyticity of general quaternionvalued functions has not been rigorously examined even if they have been implemented in [31]. Very stringent Cauchy-Riemann-Fueter (CRF) and the generalized Cauchy-Riemann conditions [32], [33] guarantee that globally analytical quaternion-valued functions are only constants and linear functions, respectively. Fortunately, up to now, many authors have studied the analyticity problem [34], i.e., they adopted a local alternative to the CRF conditions, namely, the local analyticity condition (LAC) [32]. Then, we can choose standard activation functions by the LAC, such as function tanh.

To the best of our knowledge, time delay is unavoidable in the real-world problems. For example, time delays may occur due to the processing and transmission of signals in the circuit implementation of neural networks, resulting from the finite switching speed of amplifiers, which may cause oscillation, instability, and other poor performance. Thus, the consideration of time delays is of great importance in the study of networks [35]- [37]. On one hand, time delays can be assumed to be bounded, i.e., τ pq (t) ≤ τ, p, q = 1, 2, . . . , n, where τ pq (t) values are time-varying delays and τ is a fixed constant. On the other hand, there are also many stability results on the unbounded time delays [38], [39]. In [38], the globally robust stability of uncertain stochastic neural networks with unbounded time-varying delays is considered, and some sufficient conditions are obtained in terms of linear matrix inequality (LMI). In [39], the problem of the global μ-stability for CVNNs with unbounded time-varying delays is considered. Using two different approaches, some criteria in the form of LMIs are reported. However, traditional methods used to solve the stability problems of CVNNs or RVNNs cannot be directly applied to the similar problems of QVNNs. Therefore, studying the dynamical behaviors of QVNNs with different methods is still open and challenging. In fact, the global μ-stability for delayed QVNNs has been investigated in the recent work [40], where the QVNN is decomposed into two complex-valued systems, which can avoid the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, and then, the Hermite matrix is used in LMIs. In this paper, Theorem 1 decomposes the QVNN into four real-valued systems, which avoids the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, while Theorem 2 investigates the QVNN with the direct method by means of quaternion selfconjugate matrices and quaternion positive definite matrices, which are used in LMIs. Compared with [40], the main challenges here are the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication and the choice of Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional with quaternion positive definite matrices, which are the main contributions in this paper. Therefore, the approach used in this paper can be regarded as a new attempt on the stability of QVNNs.

Motivated by the above-mentioned considerations, in this paper, we investigate the global μ-stability of QVNNs with unbounded time-varying delays and further generalize the existing results in [39]. In order to avoid the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, the QVNN is decomposed into four real-valued systems based on Hamilton rules; then, some conditions are obtained by the means of the real-valued Lyapunov function method. Considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, the considered QVNN is investigated directly by combining the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional method, the quaternion-valued LMI technique, and some quaternion positive definite matrices, based on which some new criteria are established to guarantee the μ-stability for the considered QVNN. The main contributions of this paper are listed as follows.

1) The global μ-stability of the delayed QVNNs is investigated by two different methods. First, avoiding the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, where the QVNN is equivalent to the four real-valued systems decomposed from the QVNN, based on which, the global μ-stability of QVNNs is easy to investigate except for the higher dimensions. Second, considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, where the QVNN is studied directly, based on which, the calculation is not too complicated. 2) Some constraints on the quaternion-valued activations are presented in Assumptions 1 and 2, respectively. Assumption 1 is mainly for the real-valued functions deriving from the quaternion-valued activation functions, and Assumption 2 is for the quaternion-valued activation functions, which are used in the method of considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication. 3) In the method of considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional and the obtained LMI are about quaternion self-conjugate matrices and quaternion positive definite matrices, because the eigenvalues of these matrices are all real-valued, which can help to facilitate the investigation.

4) The relationships between time-varying delays and some special stabilities are also presented. That is, the μ-stability can be specified into some special stabilities along with the changing of time-varying delays, which can affect the convergence rates of the considered QVNN. The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the system description is provided, as well as some basic definitions and assumptions. Sufficient conditions are derived for the global μ-stability of QVNNs with different methods in Section III. In Section IV, two numerical examples are given to show the effectiveness of main results. Finally, Section V concludes this paper.

Notations: In this paper, R m×n , C m×n , and Q m×n denote, respectively, the set of all m × n real-valued, complex-valued, and quaternion-valued matrices. SC n (Q) and SC > n (Q) are the set of all quaternion self-conjugate matrices and quaternion positive definite matrices, respectively. Function h(t) = x R (t) + i x I (t) + j x J (t) + kx K (t) denotes the quaternionvalued function, where x R (t), x I (t), x J (t), x K (t) are all realvalued functions, and i , j , and k obey Hamilton rules:
div.formula: i j = -ji = k, jk = -k j = i, ki = -ik = j, i 2 = j 2 = k 2 = i jk = -1, which result in the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication. For any h ∈ Q, h = √ hh * = ((x R ) 2 + (x I ) 2 + (x J ) 2 + (x K ) 2 ) 1/2 , where h * = x R -i x I - j x J -kx K denotes the conjugate transpose of h. h(t) {ξ,∞} = max p |ξ p h p (t)|, p = 1, 2, . . . , n. If vector x ∈ Q n , x * denotes the conjugate transpose of x. If matrix A ∈ Q n×n , Ā, A * ,
div.p: and λ max (A)(λ min (A)) denote the conjugate, the conjugate transpose, and the maximum (minimum) eigenvalue of A, respectively.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Consider the following QVNN with unbounded timevarying delays:
div.formula: ḣ p (t) = -d p h p (t) + n q=1 a pq g q (h q (t)) + n q=1 b pq g q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) + u p (1)
div.p: for p = 1, 2, . . . , n. h p (t) denotes the state of the pth neuron at time t, and
div.formula: h(t) = (h 1 (t), h 2 (t), . . . , h n (t)) T ∈ Q n is the state vector of QVNN (1). D = diag(d 1 , d 2 , . . . , d n ) ∈ R n×n with d p > 0 denotes the self-feedback connection weight matrix, p = 1, 2, . . . , n. A = (a pq ) n×n ∈ Q n×n and B = (b pq ) n×n ∈ Q n×n are
div.p: , respectively, the connection weight matrices without and with time delays. g q (h q (t)) and g q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) denote the quaternion-valued activation functions without and with time delays, respectively. τ pq ≥ 0, p, q = 1, 2, . . . , n, represent the time-varying delays. u p ∈ Q is the pth external input. The initial values can be expressed as
div.formula: h p (s) = p (s) ∈ Q, s ∈ (-∞, 0], p = 1, 2, . . . , n. Assumption 1: Let h = x R +i x I + j x J +kx K , τ t := t -τ (t),
div.p: and the functions g q (h) and g q (h(t -τ (t))) can be expressed similarly as
div.formula: g q (h) = g R q (x R , x I , x J , x K ) + ig I q (x R , x I , x J , x K ) + jg J q (x R , x I , x J , x K ) + kg K q (x R , x I , x J , x K ) g q (h(τ t )) = g R q (x R (τ t ), x I (τ t ), x J (τ t ), x K (τ t )) + ig I q (x R (τ t ), x I (τ t ), x J (τ t )) + jg J q (x R (τ t ), x I (τ t ), x J (τ t ), x K (τ t )) + kg K q (x R (τ t ), x I (τ t ), x J (τ t ), x K (τ t ))
div.p: where g l q (•, •, •, •) : R 4 → R, l = R, I, J, K , and the following hold.
1) The partial derivatives of g q (x R , x I , x J , x K ) with respect to x R , x I , x J , x K exist and are continuous. It is similar to the partial derivatives of
div.formula: g q (x R τ , x I τ , x J τ , x K τ ) with respect to x R τ , x I τ , x J τ , x K τ , where x l (t -τ (t)) x l τ , l = R, I, J, K .
div.p: 2) The partial derivatives mentioned earlier are all bounded, that is, there exist positive constants λ l 1 l 2 q , where l 1 ,
div.formula: l 2 = R, I, J, K , such that |(∂g l 1 q (x R , x I , x J , x K )/∂(x l 2 ))| ≤ λ l 1 l 2 q and |(∂g l 1 q (x R τ , x I τ , x J τ , x K τ )/∂(x l 2 τ ))| ≤ δ l 1 l 2 q .
div.p: According to the mean valued theorem for multivariable functions, for
div.formula: x l i ∈ R and x l iτ x l i (t -τ (t)), i = 1, 2, l = R, I, J, K ,, one get |g l q (x R 1 , x I 1 , x J 1 , x K 1 ) - g l q (x R 2 , x I 2 , x J 2 , x K 2 )| ≤ λ l R q |x R 1 -x R 2 | + λ l I q |x I 1 -x I 2 | + λ l J q |x J 1 -x J 2 | + λ l K q |x K 1 -x K 2 |, and |g l q (x R 1τ , x I 1τ , x J 1τ , x K 1τ ) - g l q (x R 2τ , x I 2τ , x J 2τ , x K 2τ )| ≤ δ l R q |x R 1τ -x R 2τ | + δ l I q |x I 1τ -x I 2τ | + δ l J q |x J 1τ -x J 2τ | + δ l K q |x K 1τ -x K 2τ |.
div.p: Combined with Assumption 1, QVNN (1) can be decomposed into four real-valued systems, which are equivalent to the QVNN. That is to say, considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication with i j
div.formula: = -ji = k, jk = -k j = i, ki = -ik = j, i 2 = j 2 = k 2 = i jk = -1 gives that ẋ R p = -d p x R p + n q=1 a R pq g R q (h q (t)) - n q=1 a I pq g I q (h q (t)) - n q=1 a J pq g J q (h q (t)) - n q=1 a K pq g K q (h q (t)) + n q=1 b R pq g R q (h q (t -τ pq (t)))- n q=1 b I pq g I q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) - n q=1 b J pq g J q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) - n q=1 b K pq g K q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) + u R p + n q=1 b R pq g K q (h q (t -τ pq (t)))+ n q=1 b K pq g R q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) + n q=1 b I pq g J q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) - n q=1 b J pq g I q (h q (t -τ pq (t))) + u K p and ẋ I p , ẋ J p , ẋ K p can be obtained similarly, in which, h = x R + x I + x J + x K , u = u R + iu I + ju J + ku K , a pq = a R pq + ia I pq + ja J pq + ka K pq , b pq = b R pq + ib I pq + jb J pq + kb K pq , A = A R + i A I + j A J + k A K = (a pq ) n×n , and B = B R + i B I + j B J + k B K = (b pq ) n×n .
div.p: Therefore, the initial values can also be expressed in the
div.formula: forms x R p (s) = R P (s) ∈ R, x I p (s) = I P (s) ∈ R, x J p (s) = J P (s) ∈ R, x K p (s) = K P (s) ∈ R, and p (s) = R P (s) + i I P (s) + j J P (s) + k K P (s) ∈ Q, s ∈ (-∞, 0], p = 1, 2, . . . , n.
div.p: Suppose that ĥ = ( ĥ1 , ĥ2 , . . . , ĥn ) T is the unique equilibrium point of QVNN (1). Let h = h -ĥ. Then, we can get the following vector form of QVNN (1):
div.formula: ḣ(t) = -D h(t) + A(g( h(t) + ĥ) -g( ĥ)) + B(g( h(t -τ (t)) + ĥ) -g( ĥ)) (2) where A = (a pq ) n×n , B = (b pq ) n×n , h(t) = ( h1 (t), h2 (t), . . . , hn (t)) T , g( h(t) + ĥ) -g( ĥ) = g 1 , . . . , g n T ,
div.p: g m = g 1 ( hm (t) + ĥm )g 1 ( ĥm ), m = 1, 2, . . . , n, g( h(tτ (t)) + ĥ)g( ĥ) = ( ĝ1 , . . . , ĝn ) T , and ĝm = g m ( hm (t -
It can be checked that the stability of the origin for QVNN (2) is equivalent to that of the equilibrium point ĥ for QVNN (1).

Assumption 2: Assume that g q (•) satisfies the Lipschitz condition in the domain of quaternions, i.e., for any μ, ν ∈ Q, q = 1, 2, . . . , n, there exists positive constant λ q , such that g q (μ)g q (ν) ≤ λ q μ -ν .
Moreover, we define

Remark 1: It can be checked that Assumption 2 is for ensuring the Lipschitz condition. Actually, Assumption 2 is a required condition on the activation functions if the QVNN is considered directly on the stability problem, and the method of choosing quaternion-valued activation functions is similar to that of complex-valued activation functions [14], [39]. However, due to Hamilton rules about quaternion multiplication, much more difficulties and changes should be considered and new tools should be used, for example, the quaternion positive definite matrices are used for the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, and the quaternion self-conjugate matrices are used in LMIs. That is, Assumption 2 is indispensable for the choices of the activation functions of QVNNs when QVNNs are considered with the direct method. Thus, Assumption 2 is relatively moderate, which is required for establishing the main results.

Assumption 3: Time-varying delay τ (t) is nonnegative and continuously differentiable and satisfies τ (t) ≤ < 1, where is a positive constant. Definition 1 [39]: A constant vector ĥ = ( ĥ1 , ĥ2 , . . . , ĥn ) T is called an equilibrium point of networks (1), if for p, q = 1, 2, . . . , n -d p ĥ p + n q=1 a pq g q ( ĥq ) + n q=1 b pq g q ( ĥq ) + u p = 0.
Definition 2 [39]: Suppose that μ(t) is a nonnegative continuous function satisfying μ(t) → ∞, as t → ∞. If there exists a constant ω, such that
div.formula: h(t) ≤ ω μ(t)
div.p: , t ≥ 0 then QVNN ( 1) is said to be μ-stable. Remark 2: In fact, the above-mentioned definition of the μ-stability includes the global asymptotical stability [42], the Lyapunov stability, power stability, exponential stability, log stability, and log-log stability [39]. The above-mentioned definition shows that h(t) → 0 along with t → ∞, which suggests that the μ-stability can imply the Lyapunov stability considering from the definition of Lyapunov stability, i.e., the system is Lyapunov stable if the states can last forever in any small range near equilibrium point. Moreover, h(t) → 0 means that the states not only maintain near the equilibrium point, but also will eventually converge to equilibrium point at a rate. That is, the μ-stability can ensure the states converge to the equilibrium resulting from the fact that μ → ∞ gives h(t) → 0, which can indeed ensure the Lyapunov stability. In addition, it can be referred from [42] that the μ-stability includes the globally asymptotic stability, which is indeed accurate from the definitions of their own. Therefore, the μ-stability can imply both the Lyapunov stability and the globally asymptotic stability considering from definitions and intuitive geometric meanings of their own [42]. In the following, some specific stabilities are presented based on different μ functions [39].

Definition 3 (Exponential Stability [39]): Suppose that nonnegative continuous function e σ t , σ > 0 satisfies e σ t → ∞, as t → ∞. If there exists a scalar ω, such that 1) is said to be exponentially stable.
div.formula: h(t) ≤ ω e σ t , t ≥ 0 then QVNN (
div.p: Definition 4 (Power Stability [39]): Suppose that nonnegative continuous function t γ , γ > 0 satisfies t γ → ∞, as t → ∞. If there exists a scalar ω > 0, such that 1) is said to be power stable.
div.formula: h(t) ≤ ω t γ , t > 0 then QVNN (
div.p: Definition 5 [43]: {ξ, ∞}-norm: h(t) {ξ,∞} = max p=1,2,...,n ξ -1 p h p (t) , where ξ p > 0, p = 1, 2, . . . , n.

In the following, we will give some related information about the quaternion matrix, including the definitions of the quaternion self-conjugate matrix and the quaternion positive definite matrix, which will play key roles for obtaining the main results. More detailed information can be referred to [44, Ch. 2].
Definition 6 [44]:
div.formula: Matrix A ∈ Q n×n is said to be a quater- nion self-conjugate matrix, i.e., A ∈ SC n (Q), if A * = A.
div.p: It is observed from the definition that the real-valued symmetric matrices and the Hermitian matrices are special quaternion self-conjugate matrices. We have a similar definition as follows.
Definition 7 [44]:
div.formula: Matrix A ∈ SC n (Q) is said to be a quaternion positive definite matrix, i.e., A ∈ SC > n (Q), if x * Ax > 0, for any x = 0, x = (x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ) T ∈ Q n×1 .
div.p: Proposition 1 [44]:
div.formula: Given matrices A ∈ Q n 1 ×n 2 and B ∈ Q n 2 ×n 3 , then (AB) * = B * A * .
div.p: Lemma 1 [44]: Given a matrix A ∈ SC n (Q), then all eigenvalues of A are real numbers.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we will give some theorems for the global μ-stability of delayed QVNN (1), as well as some corollaries for exponential stability and power stability.
Theorem 1: Assume that Assumption 1 and τ pq (t) ≤ τ (t) hold. Function μ(t) is nonnegative and continuously differentiable, and it satisfies
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ lim t →∞ μ(t) = ∞, lim t →∞ μ(t) μ(t) = α lim t →∞ μ(t) μ(t -τ (t)) = 1 + β
div.p: where α and β are nonnegative scalars. Then, QVNN (1) has a unique equilibrium point ĥ, which is globally μ-stable, if there exist positive constants ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ n , such that
div.formula: ξ p (-d p + α) + n q=1 ξ q a R pq + a I pq + a J pq + a K pq × λ Rl q + λ Il q + λ J l q + λ K l q + n q=1 ξ q b R pq + b I pq + b J pq + b K pq (1 + β) × δ Rl q + δ Il q + δ J l q + δ K l q < 0
div.p: hold for p = 1, 2, . . . , n and l = R, I, J, K .

Proof: First, we can know from [43] and [45, Th. 2] that there is a unique equilibrium point ĥ of QVNN (1). Next, we will show that the above-mentioned conditions imply the global μ-stability of the equilibrium of QVNN (1).

Suppose ĥ = ( ĥ1 , ĥ2 , . . . , ĥn ) T is the unique equilibrium point of QVNN (1). Let h = h -ĥ, and we can get the following vector form of QVNN (1): ḣ p (t) = -d p h p (t) + n q=1 a pq gq ( hq ) + n q=1 b pq gq ( hτ q ), where gq ( hq ) = g q ( hq (t) + ĥq )g q ( ĥq ), gq ( hτ q ) = g q ( hq (tτ pq (t)) + ĥq )g q ( ĥq ).
Then, one has
div.formula: ẋ R p = -d p x R p + n q=1 a R p,q g R q ( hq ) - n q=1 a I p,q gI q ( hq ) -n q=1 a J p,q g J q ( hq ) -n q=1 a K p,q gK q ( hq ) + n q=1 b R p,q g R q ( hτ q ) -n q=1 b I p,q gI q ( hτ q ) -n q=1 b J p,q g J q ( hτ q ) - n q=1 b K p,q
div.p: gK q ( hτ q ), and ẋ I p , ẋ J p , ẋ K p can be obtained similarly, where gl q ( hq ) = g l q ( hq (t)+ ĥq )g l q ( ĥq ), gl q ( hτ q ) = g l q ( hq (tτ pq (t)) + ĥq )g l q ( ĥq ), l = R, I, J, K .
By Assumption 1, one has | gl

where

div.p: Then, there exists > 0, such that (t) = (t 0 ), for any t ∈ (t 0 , t 0 + ). Defining (t) = (T ), for any t > T , T ≥ 0, it can be checked that V ( h(t)) {ξ,∞} ≤

div.head: (T ) and h(t) {ξ,∞} ≤ ( (T )/μ(t)). Consequently, QVNN (1) is globally μ-stable by Definition 2.
div.p: Remark 3: Actually, the concept of μ-stability is a generalization of some stability results, such as exponential stability, power stability, log stability, and log-log stability, which can be obtained by confining the bounds of time delays [39]. That is, there is a relationship between the four stabilities and the time-varying delays resulting in the different convergence rates. If τ pq (t) ≤ τ , the stability becomes exponential stability whose convergence rate is much faster compared with that of other three stabilities. If τ pq (t) ≤ λt, λ < 1, the stability becomes power stability whose convergence rate is much faster compared with that of other two stabilities. If τ pq (t) ≤ t -(t/ln t), the stability becomes log stability whose convergence rate is faster than log-log stabilities, and the stability becomes log-log stability, if τ pq (t) ≤ tt α , 0 < α < 1.

For different stabilities, the corresponding μ function is necessary according to Definition 2, that is, the choice of function μ depends on the desired stability, such as exponential stability with τ pq (t) ≤ τ , where μ is chosen as e σ t , σ > 0 with lim t →∞ μ(t) = ∞, lim t →∞ ( μ(t)/μ(t)) = σ := α, and lim t →∞ (μ(t)/μ(t -τ (t))) = 1 + β ≤ e σ τ , which can be guaranteed by choosing appropriate nonnegative scalar β and positive scalar σ . That is, for the desired stability, any μ function satisfying the three conditions in Theorem 1 is fine, including exponential stability with μ(t) = e σ t , σ > 0, power stability with μ(t) = t γ , γ > 0, log stability with μ(t) = ln(1+t), and log-log stability with μ(t) = ln ln (3+t), which can be referred to [39] for more detailed information.

Remark 4: Moreover, the sufficient condition obtained in Theorem 1 requires that d p should be larger than α. And the choice of the μ-function with α small enough can be realized. As shown earlier, the choice of the μ-function depends on the desired stability determined by the bound of the time delay. For example, for exponential stability with μ(t) = e σ t , σ > 0, where σ := α, that is, to make the inequality hold, then the convergence rate parameter α = σ should be smaller than d p , which can be realized by choosing a comparatively small parameter σ ≤ min 1≤ p≤n {d p }. For different neural networks with different self-feedback connection weight matrices
div.formula: D = diag(d 1 , d 2 , . . . , d n ) ∈ R n×n ,
div.p: the choice for the convergence rate parameter σ is also different.
Remark 5: Essentially, quaternions are more complicated than complex numbers because of Hamilton rules:
div.formula: i j = -ji = k, jk = -k j = i, ki = -ik = j, i 2 = j 2 = k 2 = i jk = -1.
div.p: Then for QVNNs, the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication makes dynamical equations of state more complicated than that of CVNNs. Correspondingly, the methods used in studying the stability of QVNNs and CVNNs are also different. On the one hand, Velmurugan et al. [39] consider the stability of CVNNs by the method of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, where the CVNN is not decomposed into real-valued systems, and some Hermitian matrices with all real-valued eigenvalues are used in the complex-valued LMIs. If the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication is considered (see Theorem 2 of this paper), then the quaternion selfconjugate matrices have to be used in the quaternion-valued Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, because the eigenvalues of these quaternion-valued matrices are all real numbers. Moreover, the choice of these quaternion self-conjugate matrices is much more difficult than that of those Hermitian matrices. On the other hand, if the QVNN is decomposed into realvalued systems, the dimensions grow four times, whereas the dimensions grow two times for the CVNN, i.e., the calculations of the QVNN are much more complicated than that of the CVNN. Moreover, the sufficient conditions in the form of quaternion-valued LMI given in Theorem 2 are more concise and compact than that given in Theorem 1 of this paper. All in all, the stability analysis of QVNNs is more complicated than that of CVNNs, due to the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, the choice of quaternion selfconjugate matrices, and the increasing dimensions.

According to Definition 2, we know that the μ-stability can be specified into power stability, exponential stability, log stability, and log-log stability resulting from different time-varying delays. Then, some conditions for the power stability are presented in the following.

Corollary 1 (Power Stability): Under Assumption 1, τ pq (t) ≤ λt, where 0 < λ < 1. If the four inequations in Theorem 1 hold, then QVNN (1) has an equilibrium point ĥ, and h(t) -ĥ {ξ,∞} = O(t -γ ), for some constant γ > 0.
Proof: Under the circumstance, we can assume that there exists a scalar γ > 0, such that -ξ
div.formula: p d p + n q=1 ξ q (|a R pq | + |a I pq | + |a J pq | + |a K pq |)(λ Rl q + λ Il q + λ J l q + λ K l q ) + (1 - λ) -γ n q=1 ξ q (|b R pq | + |b I pq | + |b J pq | + |b K pq |)(δ Rl q + δ Il q + δ J l q + δ K l q ) < 0, where l = R, I, J, K . Choosing μ(t) = t γ , we can get lim t →∞ ( μ(t)/μ(t)) = lim t →∞ (γ t γ -1 /t γ ) = 0 and lim t →∞ (μ(t)/μ(t -τ (t))) = (1 -λ) -γ . Considering (1 -λ) -γ
div.p: with 0 < λ < 1 and γ > 0, it can be checked that 0 < (1 -λ) < 1, i.e., (1/(1 -λ) γ ) > 1 can be guaranteed with some γ > 0, which shows that the results in Corollary 1 can be ensured by Theorem 1. That is to say, Theorem 1 gives that h(t) -ĥ {ξ,∞} = O(t -γ ).

Considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, in the following, QVNN (1) is directly investigated to establish some new sufficient conditions for the global μ-stability of the QVNN with the techniques of the quaternionvalued Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, the quaternion-valued LMI, and the quaternion positive definite matrices.

Then, it is obtained that h(t) 2 ≤ (ω/μ(t)), t ≥ 0, with ω = (V 0 /λ min (P)). Thus, QVNN (1) is μ-stable by Definition 2.
Corollary 2 (Exponential Stability): Assume that τ (t) ≤ τ , where τ is a constant and μ(t) = e σ t , σ > 0. If LMI (4) holds, then QVNN (1) is exponentially stable.

div.head: Proof:
div.p: We can obtain from μ(t) = e σ t that lim t →∞ ( μ(t)/μ(t)) = lim t →∞ (σ e σ t /e σ t ) = σ and lim t →∞ (μ(t -τ (t))/μ(t)) = lim t →∞ (e σ (t -τ ) /e σ t ) = e -σ τ . In virtue of Theorem 2 and Definition 3, there exists a scalar ω > 0, such that h(t) 2 ≤ ωe -σ t , t ≥ 0. Therefore, QVNN (1) is exponentially stable.

Remark 6: Actually, continuously differentiable or monotonically increasing activation functions are frequently used in RVNNs [46]- [49], while Assumption 2, in this paper, about the quaternion-valued activation function relaxes the constraints for activation functions, that is, the Lipschitz condition is relatively less conservative. Moreover, compared with [14] and [41] for CVNNs where main results are obtained under the assumptions that, the partial derivatives of the real and imaginary parts of CVNNs are confined to be existent, continuous, and bounded. While the considered QVNNs are reduced to CVNNs or RVNNs, the Lipschitz condition of Assumption 2 will be less conservative than the assumptions given by [14], [41], and [46]- [49].

div.head: IV. EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, two numerical examples are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed results.
Example 1: Consider a 2-D QVNN with unbounded timevarying delays ḣ p (t) = -d p h p (t) + 2 q=1 a pq g q (h q (t))

b pq g q (h q (t -τ pq (t))), p = 1, 2 (9) where h = x R + i x I + j x J + kx K ∈ Q = δ l 1 l 2 q = 0.01, for q = 1, 2. l 1 , l 2 = R, I, J, K . Let μ(t) = t, α = β = 0.1, and the activation function be g(h) = tanh h.

Calculation gives that the following inequalities in Theorem 1 are satisfied with ξ p = 0.1, p = 1, 2, i.e., ξ p (- 9) is globally μ-stable. Fig. 1 shows the state trajectories of QVNN (9) with initial value x( 0 10) is globally μ-stable. Fig. 2 shows the state trajectories of QVNN (10) with initial value x( 0
div.formula: d p + α) + n q=1 ξ q (|a R pq | + |a I pq | + |a J pq | + |a K pq |)(λ Rl q + λ Il q + λ J l q + λ K l q ) + n q=1 ξ q (|b R pq | + |b I pq | + |b J pq | + |b K pq |)(1 + β)(δ Rl q + δ Il q + δ J l q + δ K l q ) < 0, l = R, I, J, K . Consequently, QVNN (
div.p: Remark 7: For the activation functions, [40, Assumption 3] is the same as Assumption 2 in this paper, which can be applied into a wide class of QVNNs, as analyzed in [40]. In this paper, the two assumptions in [39] are relaxed to a mild one, i.e., the quaternion-valued activation functions satisfy the Lipschitz condition given in Assumption 3 here. Compared with [39, Assumption 1] and [41, Definitions 2 and 3], Assumption 2 in this paper is a moderate one where the activation functions satisfy the Lipschitz condition as an entirety. That is, Assumption 2 in this paper gives a wider class of the quaternion-valued activation functions. Thereby, compared with the Lipschitz condition and the restriction on time delays as in [40], the considered examples in this paper can be analyzed with the complex decomposition method, and then guaranteed by the results of [40], which can be regarded as the third method on the analysis of QVNNs apart from the direct and decomposition methods used in this paper. Actually, to the best of our knowledge, this paper is a first attempt on the direct method (Theorem 2) to study the stability of QVNNs, which potentially has wide applications in the related areas in the future investigations.

Remark 8: In fact, lots of evidence show that, compared with the traditional numerical methods, neural networks have many advantages, which have been detailedly analyzed in [11] and [12]. For the optimization problems on the one hand, to minimize the objective function such as in [11], they design a neural network (6) based on the projection function. Considering the proposed neural networks in this paper, it is potentially possible that the proposed neural networks can be applied to the optimization problems, since the QVNNs Fig. 2. Time responses and state trajectories of x R (t), x I (t), x J (t), x K (t), which shows the global μ-stability of the equilibrium of QVNN (10). can be deduced into the general RVNNs when the coefficients of i, j, k are equivalent to zero. However, due to the special characteristics of quaternion induced by Hamilton rules: i j =ji = k, jk = -k j = i , ki = -ik = j , i 2 = j 2 = k 2 = -1, maybe QVNNs could solve some special optimization problems (such as minimizing the model of the quaternion-valued objective function in some practice problems), where the projection function is quaternion-valued. On the other hand, Cheng et al. [12] have applied the designed neural network to solve linear variational inequalities, which is irradiative for the practical applications of the QVNNs. However, as shown in this paper that, we focus on the fundamental problem of the considered QVNNs, so in the next step, we will also consider the deeper problems similar to the cases of RVNNs, including designing appropriate neural networks for such as solving optimization problems and for solving linear variational inequalities [11], [12]. However, the theory investigations and the application investigations are not easy, and these application investigations will be a challenged and interesting topic in the future work.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the global μ-stability problem of QVNNs with unbounded time-varying delays is investigated. By considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication and unbounded time-varying delays, two different methods are used in this paper. One is avoiding the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, that is, the QVNN is first decomposed into four real-valued systems, which are equivalent to the original QVNN. And then, some sufficient conditions are, respectively, presented to guarantee the global μ-stability and the power stability of the addressed QVNN with the Lyapunov function method. The other is considering the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication, where the QVNN is investigated directly. By the means of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional method and the quaternion-valued LMI technique, some new criteria are, respectively, derived for the global μ-stability and the exponential stability for the considered QVNN. In the direct method, the noncommutativity of quaternion multiplication and the choice of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional about quaternion matrices are two challenges. Finally, numerical examples are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the present results. Further investigations about QVNNs will consider the optimization approach [5], the optimization problem [11] and the linear variational inequalities problem [12], the controllability [50] and the synchronization [51] based on the self-triggered control method [2], and the pinning control method [53]. Moreover, at present and in the future, we are focusing on the real-world applications of QVNNs, including QVNN-based color face recognition, QVNN-based color image compression, and QVNN-based color night vision.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: The authors would like to thank Prof. Y. Tang for his patient guidance and valuable suggestions, who is with the Key Laboratory of Advanced Control and Optimization for Chemical Processes, Ministry of Education, East China University of Science and Technology. They would like to thank Prof. Q. Song of Chongqing Jiaotong University for valuable suggestions and W. Zhang of Tianjin University for valuable discussions. They would also like to thank anonymous reviewers for helpful comments that improved this paper.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 11671361, Grant 61573102, Grant 61772199, and Grant 61573096, in part by the China Postdoctoral Science Foundation under Grant 2016T90406, Grant 2015M580378, and Grant 2014M560377, and in part by the Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation under Grant LY14A010008 and Grant LY15F020018.

Her current research interests include quaternionvalued neural networks, networked control systems, multiagent systems/complex networks, cyberphysical systems, hybrid dynamical systems, stochastic systems, and their applications in practical engineering.
